awd_titl_txt: SI2-SSE: Genetic Algorithm Software Package for Prediction of Novel Two-Dimensional Materials and Surface Reconstructions
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to control structure and composition at the nanoscale has introduced exciting scientific and technological opportunities. Advances in the creation of nanomaterials such as single-layer materials and nanocrystals have led to improved understanding of basic structure-property relationships that, in turn, have enabled impressive progress in a broad range of nanotechnologies with applications for energy storage, catalysis and electronic devices. Yet, significant knowledge gaps persist in what single-layer materials could be synthesized and in our understanding of the nature of the surfaces of nanocrystals, particularly in the complex environment of solvents and ligands. The discovery of potentially stable novel single-layer materials and the prediction of nanocrystal surface structures are arguably among the most critical aspects of nanoscale materials. This research will provide the computational tools for the detailed prediction of the structure of two-dimensional materials and nanostructure surfaces in complex environments. This will impact the development and the design of novel nanomaterials with properties optimized for applications ranging from catalyst for chemical reactions, to energy conversion materials, to low-power and high-speed electronic devices.
	
Progress in the field requires better computational methods for structure prediction. This project will (i) transform the Genetic Algorithm for Structure Prediction (GASP) software package developed by the PI into a sustainable scientific tool, (ii) extend its functionality to 2D materials and materials interfaces, and (iii) increase its performance by coupling to surrogate energy models that are optimized on the fly. These complementary goals will be achieved through expansion of the developer and user base, transition to portable software interfaces and data structures, and the addition of modular algorithms for functionality and performance enhancements. To enhance the functionality, the GASP algorithms will be extended to two two-dimensional materials and materials surfaces with adsorbates and ligands. To enhance the performance of the genetic algorithm, the optimization approach will be coupled to surrogate energy models such as machine-learning techniques and empirical energy models that are optimized on the fly. The publication of user tutorials, and documentation on the data structures and software interfaces will enhance the GASP codes overall utility, increase the user and developer base, and enable further extension to other data-mining and structure prediction approaches. The students involved in this project will receive extensive training and experience in algorithm development, scientific computation, and structure/property determination of complex nanomaterials. As part of the education and outreach component of the project, the PI will develop a course module on Materials Structure Predictions and widely distribute it. A weeklong workshop for students and postdocs in the third year of the project on Materials Discovery and Design will broaden the research?s impact beyond the creation of new software and the discovery of novel single-layer materials and nanocrystal surface and ligand configurations.

por.por_cntn:
The ability to control structure and composition at the nanoscale provides exciting scientific and technological opportunities. Since the discovery of graphene, the field of low-dimensional materials and research on the discovery, characterization, and application of novel low-dimensional materials has grown exponentially. Computational methods can provide insight and predict the structures and properties of low-dimensional materials. This research developed the computational algorithms and implemented the software tools for the detailed prediction of the structure of low-dimensional materials and nanostructure surfaces in complex environments and applied the tools to a variety of materials systems. 
Intellectual merit. This project developed two software packages: (i) The MPInterfaces software package automates the high-throughput computational screening and study of interfacial systems. The framework encompasses the creation and manipulation of interface structures for solid/solid heterostructures, solid/implicit solvents systems, nanoparticle/ligands systems; and the creation of simple system-agnostic workflows for in-depth computational analysis using density-functional theory or empirical energy models. The package leverages existing open-source high-throughput tools such as Pymatgen and extends their capabilities towards building knowledge of interfacial systems. (ii) The Genetic Algorithm for Structure Prediction (GASP) software package is our grand-canonical genetic algorithm that can accurately predict how atoms arrange into a crystal or molecular structures and to determine the composition of the ground state phases of materials without any prior information about the system. Our approach is unique in that it predicts not only the structure of materials but also the composition. We recently extended our GASP algorithm to enable unbiased searching for the compositions and structures of novel low-dimensional materials with low formation energies and finite layer thicknesses. Also, we developed machine-learning models that can learn the energy landscape on the fly and be coupled to the structure search to increase its performance.
We applied these tools to discover and characterize many novel 2D materials and materials interfaces with unique properties ranging from semiconducting and metallic to piezoelectrics, magnetic, and half-metallic behavior. In addition to openly distributing the software tools we develop, at Github, https://github.com/henniggroup, we are also freely distributing the data from our studies through our MaterialsWeb database, which is available at https://materialsweb.org. 
Broader impacts. The software and the materials discovered have the potential to impact the development and the design of novel nanomaterials with properties optimized for applications ranging from catalysts for chemical reactions to energy conversion materials to low-power and high-speed electronic devices. The publication of user tutorials and documentation on Github allows new users and developers to apply and extend the software to other materials science problems. The scientific community uses these software packages at other universities and national laboratories in the U.S. and Europe. The project trained three graduate students in algorithm development, scientific computation, and structure/property determination of complex nanomaterials. The three students graduated with their Ph.D. and continue in the field of software engineering and materials design in industry and at national labs.
